Derek James wrote:

>On Mon, 02 Aug 2004 22:33:46 +0100, Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
>  
>
>>This is all on done on purpose because I didn't want a full
>>blown OCR experiment as such, I just wanted a problem domain that could
>>be used to test NEATs ability to search through a large connection space
>>and that would execute at high speed - this domain achieves those
>>requirements.
>>    
>>
>
>Ah...gotcha.  Thanks for the recap. :)
>
>Yeah, I understand that this is just a sort of test domain.  If you
>had any variance in your input, it wouldn't work.
>
Well, it would require a more complex network to handle variance. 
Whether such a network could be found I don't know.

>  This is probably
>more akin to a memorization task than a pattern recognition one, since
>there's no noise or variance in your samples.
>  
>
Yeh, In formal NN lingo I think it comes under pattern classification.

>>50x50 represnts a massive input space, but since I understand you're
>>using a roving eye technique that seems reasonable to me, although
>>personally I would be tempted to start a bit smaller.
>>    
>>
>
>You think that's big...some of the images for other patterns we want
>to experiment with are an order of magnitude bigger: about 300x400. :)
>  
>
Have you decided on a resolution/size for your roving eye yet? I was 
thinking about how a human eye recognises characters and it occurs to me 
that when reading we can actually read not only whole characters but 
whole words at a time, certainly our eyes don't 'rove' to detect 
individual characters. Therefore if I was going to try and construct a 
robust OCR network I think I'd tend towards a roving eye with quite a 
high resolution(good enough to distinguish all of the characters anyhow) 
that could see whole characters at a time - but then could rove (move 
and zoom in/out) in order to frame characters within the eye's field of 
view. I wonder if this technique could then be extended to read text 
from a printed sheet - or even handriting?  I know there are already 
technqiues for reading printed text, what I don't know is how good they 
are and if a roving eye technqiue could perhaps improve on the current 
best technique.

Colin.
